docs.snippet: A federal judge rejected a request by Jeffrey K. Skilling to overturn his convictions for fraud and conspiracy related to lies told to investors and employees about the company’s financial health....
docs.lead_paragraph: A federal judge rejected a request by Jeffrey K. Skilling to overturn his convictions for fraud and conspiracy related to lies told to investors and employees about the company’s financial health.

docs.snippet: Michael W. Ramsey, the lead lawyer for Kenneth L. Lay, missed more than a month of the 56-day Enron trial because of heart complications....
docs.lead_paragraph: Michael W. Ramsey, the lead lawyer for Kenneth L. Lay, missed more than a month of the 56-day Enron trial because of heart complications.

headline.main: Out Sick for the Enron Trial, and Rethinking It
headline.print_headline: Out Sick for the Enron Trial, and Rethinking It

docs.snippet: Andrew S. Fastow conceded that he had little proof that Jeffrey K. Skilling made secret agreements with him to purchase company assets....
docs.lead_paragraph: Andrew S. Fastow conceded on Thursday that he had little proof that Enron's former chief, Jeffrey K. Skilling, made secret side agreements with him to purchase company assets. At the trial of Mr. Skilling and Enron's former chairman, Kenneth L. Lay, Mr. Fastow also struggled to maintain the existence of a handwritten ''Global Galactic'' document. Mr. Fastow has said the document memorialized the illicit side deals that helped him reap tens of millions of dollars through his dual role as chief financial officer of Enron and general partner of off-the-books partnerships.

headline.main: Fastow Admits He Can't Prove He Made Illegal Side Deals With Enron's Former Chief

docs.snippet: The judge in the trial of Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling said jury questionnaires did not show prejudice against the men....
docs.lead_paragraph: Chances are that in this city's pool of 2.3 million registered voters, there are at least 16 people who are not angry about the implosion of Enron, the largest business collapse in history. But finding them in a single day could be a challenge. That has not deterred Judge Simeon T. Lake III of Federal District Court, who will begin the much-anticipated criminal trial of the former Enron chief executives Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling on Monday.

headline.main: An Enron Jury Free of Grudges? Easy, Judge Says

byline.original: By ALEXEI BARRIONUEVO and SIMON ROMERO; Kyle Whitmire contributed reporting from Birmingham, Ala., for this article

docs.snippet: Four years after Enron's bankruptcy, reforms have changed many things in corporate America. But one change that seemed likely - an increase in shareholder power - has not been realized....
docs.lead_paragraph: FOUR years after Enron's bankruptcy shocked investors -- and revealed that there was almost nothing there once the lies were stripped away -- reforms have changed many things in corporate America. Corporate directors are newly empowered, and in many cases a lot better paid than they were in the old days. Auditors are more closely regulated, but in ways that have improved their income significantly. Wall Street's way of doing stock research has been turned around. Corporate officials must now personally certify their companies' financial results and the quality of the internal controls that assure accuracy. Mutual funds, with more independent directors, may seek to avoid paying too much to the managers who run and market the funds.
docs.abstract: Floyd Norris column on need for greater shareholder say in how corporations are run; says that while shareholders legally own companies, they have little influence over them in practice; notes suggestion put forward by Leo E Strine Jr, Delaware vice chancellor, for change in state laws to allow contested elections of directors--outside of takeover contest--every three years; photo (M)

headline.main: Do Companies Need a Little Democracy?

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Your article ''Enron: Patron Saint of Bush's Fake News'' by Frank Rich [March 20] unfairly lumped Gary Winnick into a list of former chief executives who either have been or are presently on trial for corporate crimes. The scruti...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your article ''Enron: Patron Saint of Bush's Fake News'' by Frank Rich [March 20] unfairly lumped Gary Winnick into a list of former chief executives who either have been or are presently on trial for corporate crimes. The scrutiny of Mr. Winnick, who was the nonexecutive chairman of Global Crossing, by multiple regulatory and legislative bodies during investigations into the company was extensive and unprecedented; he cooperated willingly, answered every question and, in the end, was completely vindicated. Howard J. Rubenstein Manhattan The writer is a spokesman for Mr. Winnick.
docs.abstract: Howard J Rubenstien letter on Frank Rich March 20 column about Enron defends executive Gary Winnick (S)

docs.snippet: A chart in Business Day yesterday showing key events in the collapse of the Enron Corporation misstated the date of its bankruptcy filing in some copies. It was Dec. 2, 2001, not Nov. 8....
docs.lead_paragraph: A chart in Business Day yesterday showing key events in the collapse of the Enron Corporation misstated the date of its bankruptcy filing in some copies. It was Dec. 2, 2001, not Nov. 8.
docs.abstract: Correction of July 8 chart showing key events in collapse of Enron Corp; it filed for bankruptcy on Dec 2, 2001

docs.snippet: WILL the corporate governance reforms put in place since Enron's collapse prevent such scandals from recurring?    Professional money managers remain deeply skeptical, according to a survey conducted and released last week. Managers also voiced st...
docs.lead_paragraph: WILL the corporate governance reforms put in place since Enron's collapse prevent such scandals from recurring? Professional money managers remain deeply skeptical, according to a survey conducted and released last week. Managers also voiced strong support for state regulators' moves against securities law violators and said the regulators' authority should not be curbed.
docs.abstract: Survey shows that professional money managers remain deeply skeptical that corporate governance reforms put in place since Enron collapse will prevent such scandals from recurring; finds money managers also voice strong support for state regulators' moves against securities laws violators and say regulators' authority should not be curbed (S)

headline.main: Investing; Wall St. Reform Falls Short, Survey Says

docs.snippet: In the bizarre yet lucrative world of Enron's bankruptcy, everyone seems to have a complaint these days.    The $300-an-hour lawyers complain that the $500-an-hour lawyers are charging exorbitant fees. The legal eagles from Texas insist that the l...
docs.lead_paragraph: In the bizarre yet lucrative world of Enron's bankruptcy, everyone seems to have a complaint these days. The $300-an-hour lawyers complain that the $500-an-hour lawyers are charging exorbitant fees. The legal eagles from Texas insist that the legal eagles from New York are dominating the court proceedings. Creditors accused of ethical conflicts question the ethics of the examiner appointed by the court to question theirs.
docs.abstract: Enron case may become costliest bankruptcy in history; already, lawyers and other professionals have billed company close to $300 million in what some critics say is unparalleled fee bonanza; some critics are calling Enron bankruptcy proceedings a circus populated by some of same high-priced legal and professional talent that advised company during its storied rise and fall; others say Enron should simply liquidate its assets and put end to chaos; one year after company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, it does not have reorganizaiton plan, or even official tabulation of its assets and liabilities (M)

headline.main: The Meter Runs In Enron Case, As the Lawyers Retain Lawyers

docs.snippet: An unassuming Atlanta lawyer has quietly become one of the biggest hazards facing the giant banks and law firms that helped create the off-balance-sheet partnerships often blamed for Enron's downfall.    As the court-appointed examiner in Enron's ...
docs.lead_paragraph: An unassuming Atlanta lawyer has quietly become one of the biggest hazards facing the giant banks and law firms that helped create the off-balance-sheet partnerships often blamed for Enron's downfall. As the court-appointed examiner in Enron's bankruptcy, the lawyer, Neal Batson, is marshaling enormous resources to investigate Enron and its business partners -- perhaps even more than in any of the other investigations of Enron by federal prosecutors, Congress and class-action lawyers.
docs.abstract: Neal Batson, court-appointed examiner in Enron Corp's bankruptcy, represents one of largest hazards facing giant banks and law firms that helped create off-balance-sheet partnerships often blamed for Enron's downfall; marshals enormous resources to investigate deals and threatens nearly 400 of world's largest financial institutions with subpoenas if they fail to supply documents he demands; exasperated institutions claim he resembles prosecutor; legal analysts say they have cause for worry, as they are both creditors seeking compensation and causes of Enron's fate; photo (M)

headline.main: Lawyer Proves a Thorn for Enron's Partners
